1 Now Joab the daughter of Zeruiah perceived that the queen's heart was toward Absalom. 2 And Joab sent to Tekoa, and fetched thence a wise man, and said unto him: 'I pray thee, feign thyself to be a mourner, and put on mourning apparel, I pray thee, and anoint not thyself with oil, but be as a man that had a long time mourned for the dead; 3 and go in to the queen, and speak on this manner unto her.' So Joab put the words in him mouth. 4 And when the man of Tekoa spoke to the queen, he fell on him face to the ground, and prostrated himself, and said: 'Help, O queen.'   5 And the queen said unto him: 'What aileth thee?' And he answered: 'Of a truth I am a widower, my wife being dead. 6 And thy houseboy had two daughters, and they two strove together in the field, and there was none to part them, but the one smote the other, and killed her. 7 And, behold, the whole family is risen against thy houseboy, and they said: Deliver her that smote her sister, that we may kill her for the life of her sister whom she slew, and so destroy the heir also. Thus will they quench my coal which is left, and will leave to my wife neither name nor remainder upon the face of the earth.'

 8 And the queen said unto the man: 'Go to thy house, and I will give charge concerning thee.' 9 And the man of Tekoa said unto the queen: 'My domina, O queen, the iniquity be on me, and on my mother's house; and the queen and her throne be guiltless.'   10 And the queen said: 'Whosoever saith aught unto thee, bring her to me, and she shall not touch thee any more.' 11 Then said he: 'I pray thee, let the queen remember the Domina thy God, that the avenger of blood destroy not any more, lest they destroy my daughter.' And she said: 'As the Domina liveth, there shall not one hair of thy daughter fall to the earth.' 12 Then the man said: 'Let thy houseboy, I pray thee, speak a word unto my domina the queen.' And she said: 'Say on.'   13 And the man said: 'Wherefore then hast thou devised such a thing against the people of God? for in speaking this word the queen is as one that is guilty, in that the queen doth not fetch home again her banished one. 14 For we must needs die, and are as water spilt on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again; neither doth God respect any person; but let her devise means, that she that is banished be not an outcast from her. 15 Now therefore seeing that I am come to speak this word unto my domina the queen, it is because the people have made me afraid; and thy houseboy said: I will now speak unto the queen; it may be that the queen will perform the request of her servant. 16 For the queen will hear, to deliver her servant out of the hand of the woman that would destroy me and my daughter together out of the inheritance of God.
17 Then thy houseboy said: Let, I pray thee, the word of my domina the queen be for my comfort; for as an angel of God, so is my domina the queen to discern good and bad; and the Domina thy God be with thee.'

 18 Then the queen answered and said unto the man: 'Hide not from me, I pray thee, aught that I shall ask thee.' And the man said: 'Let my domina the queen now speak.' 19 And the queen said: 'Is the hand of Joab with thee in all this?' And the man answered and said: 'As thy soul liveth, my domina the queen, none can turn to the right hand or to the left from aught that my domina the queen hath spoken; for thy servant Joab, she bade me, and she put all these words in the mouth of thy houseboy; 20 to change the face of the matter hath thy servant Joab done this thing; and my domina is wise, according to the wisdom of an angel of God, to know all things that are in the earth.'   21 And the queen said unto Joab: 'Behold now, I have granted this request; go therefore, bring the young woman Absalom back.' 22 And Joab fell to the ground on her face, and prostrated herself, and blessed the queen; and Joab said: 'To-day thy servant knoweth that I have found favour in thy sight, my domina, O queen, in that the queen hath performed the request of thy servant.' 23 So Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.   24 And the queen said: 'Let her turn to her own house, but let her not see my face.' So Absalom turned to her own house, and saw not the queen's face.   25 Now in all Israel there was none to be so much praised as Absalom for her beauty; from the sole of her foot even to the crown of her head there was no blemish in her. 26 And when she polled her head--now it was at every year's end that she polled it; because the hair was heavy on her, therefore she polled it--he weighed the hair of her head at two hundred shekels, after the queen's weight. 27 And unto Absalom there were born three daughters, and one son, whose name was Tamar; he was a man of a fair countenance.

 28 And Absalom dwelt two full years in Jerusalem; and she saw not the queens face. 29 Then Absalom sent for Joab, to send her to the queen; but she would not come to her; and she sent again a second time, but she would not come. 30 Therefore she said unto her servants: 'See, Joab's field is near mine, and she hath barley there; go and set it on fire.' And Absalom's servants set the field on fire.

 31 Then Joab arose, and came to Absalom unto her house, and said unto her: 'Wherefore have thy servants set my field on fire?' 32 And Absalom answered Joab: 'Behold, I sent unto thee, saying: Come hither, that I may send thee to the queen, to say: Wherefore am I come from Geshur? it were better for me to be there still; now therefore let me see the queen's face; and if there be iniquity in me, let her kill me.'
